revisions.rev:
[[Steampunk]] is a subgenre of [[fantasy fiction|fantasy]] and [[speculative fiction]] that came into prominence in the 1980s and early 1990s. The term denotes works set in an era or world where [[steam power]] is still widely usedâusually the 19th century, and often set in [[Victorian era]] [[England]]âbut with prominent elements of either [[science fiction]] or fantasy, such as fictional technological inventions like those found in the works of [[H. G. Wells]] and [[Jules Verne]], or real technological developments like the computer occurring at an earlier date. Other examples of steampunk contain [[alternate history]]-style presentations of "the path not taken" of such technology as [[dirigible]]s or [[analog computers]]; these frequently are presented in an idealized light, or with a presumption of functionality. Although many works now considered seminal to the genre were published in the 1960s and 1970s, the term ''steampunk'' originated in the late 1980s as a [[tongue in cheek]] variant of [[cyberpunk]]. This article is a list of works in the science fiction and fantasy genres considered by commentators to be steampunk. ==Precursors== Although the term âsteampunkâ was not coined until 1987, several works of fiction significant to the development of the genre were produced before that. ''[[Titus Alone]]'' by [[Mervyn Peake]], published in 1959, anticipated many of the tropes of steampunk.Sophie Lewis, Lucy Daniel (ed.), The little black book: Books, "Titus Alone" p.439, Octopus publishing, (2007) US, isbn= 978-1-84403605-9 Steampunk was particularly influenced by, and often adopts the style of the [[scientific romance]]s and [[fantasy|fantasies]] of the 19th century. Notably influential authors are: * [[G. K. Chesterton]][[John Clute]] & [[John Grant (writer)|John Grant]],''[[The Encyclopedia of Fantasy]]'', "Steampunk", p.895 1st Ed., (1997), Orbit, ISBN 1857238974 * [[Charles Dickens]] * [[Albert Robida]] * [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] * [[George Griffith]] * [[Robert Louis Stevenson]] * [[Bram Stoker]] * [[Jules Verne]]{{cite web |last=Ottens |first=Nick | title = The darker, dirtier side | year = 2008 | url = http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/dieselpunk_articles-1.php | accessdate=2008-05-18 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110717212216/http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/dieselpunk_articles-1.php |archivedate=17 July 2011 }} * [[H. G. Wells]] * [[Mark Twain]] * [[Mary Shelley]].{{cite web| author = Strickland, Jonathan | title = Famous Steampunk Works | publisher = [[HowStuffWorks]] | url = http://electronics.howstuffworks.com/steampunk4.htm | accessdate=2008-05-18}} * [[H. P. Lovecraft]]{{cite web| author = Gareth Branwyn | title = Steam-Driven Dreams: The Wondrously Whimsical World of Steampunk | publisher = [[Wired.com]] | date=06.18.07 | url = http://www.wired.com/gadgets/mods/multimedia/2007/06/gallery_steampunk?slide=15 | quote=While the world of H.P. Lovecraft's horror is not exactly the same as that envisioned in steampunk, there's plenty of leakage between the two... | accessdate=2011-01-02}} Early adaptations of this scientific romance literature genre to film, particularly those from the 1950s and 1960s, are notable precursors of steampunk cinema: *''[[20,000 Leagues Under the Sea (1954 film)|20,000 Leagues Under the Sea]]'' (1954, film) *''[[The Time Machine (1960 film)|The Time Machine]]'' (1960, film) *''[[Master of the World (1961 film)|Master of the World]]'' (1961, film) *''[[Captain Nemo and the Underwater City]]'' (1969, film) == In literature == {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! style="background:#c60; width=9%" | Year ! style="background:#c60; width=25%" | Author(s) ! style="background:#c60; width=25%" | Title ! style="background:#c60; width=10%" | First Publisher ! style="background:#c60; width=3%" | Note ! style="background:#c60; width=3%" class="unsortable"| Ref. |- style="background:#fffff6" | align="center" | [[1967 in literature|1967]]
